items.title: A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins
items.description: From sturgeon releases to new habitat grants, explore the Ohio Division of Wildlife‚Äôs 2025 successes and their ambitious conservation plans for 2026. The post A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Added 1,686 acres of habitat to wildlife areas, accepted 122 acres from The Nature Conservancy, and protected riparian habitat.
- The population of human-raised 3-year-old eastern hellbenders surpassed 2,000 through partnerships with zoos and schools.
- Provided $20,000 in Wildlife Education grants to over 4,000 educators and students for habitat creation and wildlife education.
- Resolved an illegal taxidermy business case with $38,000 in restitution.
- Completed 4,800 acres of timber stand improvement, 6,000 acres of aerial herbicide spraying, and managed 9,420 acres of wetlands.
- Certified 208 adult 4-H shooting sports instructors and trained over 240 youth.
- Documented over 450 bee species, but 70 may be extirpated from the state.
- Stocked 2,000 juvenile lake sturgeon in the Cuyahoga River, 750 in the Sandusky River, and 3,000 in the Maumee River.
- Supported H2Ohio wetland restoration projects on 870 private acres and 6 additional sites.
- Studied wild turkey, gray fox, and black bear populations through banding, GPS collaring, and surveys.
- Launched a deer donation program to provide venison to food banks.

2026 Initiatives:
- $9 million Wildlife Habitat Initiative to restore grasslands and wildlife habitats on private lands.
- Conclude wild turkey nesting/survival study in 2026, continue monitoring into 2027.
- Launch voluntary outfitter accreditation program to improve reputation and communication.
- Re-launch Backyard for Wildlife program to help landowners create wildlife habitat.
- Continue Ohio Bear Project to study black bear status.
- Launch Sauger Restoration Plan to reestablish natural reproduction in the Maumee and Sandusky rivers.
- Replace 2 aging aircraft with a new P68C plane for law enforcement and wildlife management.

items.title: Texas A&M center named for Hood Family Foundation
items.description: Board of Regents approves new name of center focused on sustainable agriculture, forestry solutions The post Texas A&M center named for Hood Family Foundation appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M University System Board of Regents has voted to rename a center focused on sustainable solutions for agriculture and forestry industries based on unbiased science. The newly named Hood Family Center for Greenhouse Gas Management in Agriculture and Forestry was launched in 2023 as a joint center of Texas A&M AgriLife Research and Texas A&M University in College Station.

The center was named after a $5 million endowment from the John and Sally Hood Family Foundation. The center aims to advance the abilities of agriculture and forestry systems to meet modern demands for safe, affordable food and fiber production on thriving working lands.

The center focuses on converging research, teaching, and extension efforts with ongoing research on the sustainability of practices like carbon capture in Texas soils and crops. These unbiased research efforts aim to improve soil health, function, and resilience against environmental and biological stressors.

"We are immensely grateful for the generous support of the Hood Family, which paved the way for this important work," said G. Cliff Lamb, Ph.D., director of AgriLife Research. "Texas A&M AgriLife is committed to leading new discoveries, technologies and emerging practices that benefit the state, the U.S. and the world."

The center's director, Nithya Rajan, Ph.D., an agronomy and agroecology professor in the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, stated, "The generous support from the Hood family is critical to our mission. We are turning science into producer-ready solutions that strengthen soil health, reduce input costs and keep working lands productive for generations."

items.title: EPA Affirms Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair
items.description: February 5, 2025 ‚Äì The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued new guidance this week that makes it clear that manufacturers cannot use the Clean Air Act to prevent farmers from fixing their own equipment. Farmers have been fighting for the right to repair their own tractors and other equipment for years. Some companies have justified […] The post EPA Affirms Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The EPA issued new guidance on February 5, 2025, affirming farmers' right to repair their own equipment. This guidance clarifies that manufacturers cannot use the Clean Air Act to prevent farmers from fixing their tractors and other farm machinery. Farmers have been fighting for this right for years, as some companies have tried to restrict repairs. The EPA's action ensures that farmers can continue to maintain and repair their equipment without facing legal barriers from manufacturers.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Farmers are now using AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without needing to click. The true indicator of content effectiveness is now attention time - whether a farmer stays engaged and explores more content.

AgWeb.com recently redesigned to increase user attention and engagement:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in mobile users reading more articles per visit

These deeper engagement metrics are more valuable to advertisers, as they signal real interest and create stronger opportunities for brand messaging to be seen and remembered. 

The article notes that in a typical visit, readers only absorb about 28% of page text, so simplifying layouts and guiding deeper engagement is key.

For advertisers, high-attention environments like the redesigned AgWeb deliver stronger brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness. This creates more value through more time with content, more exposure opportunities per session, and better alignment with how farmers search today.

The article concludes that if the goal is to reach farmers in focused, engaged moments, AgWeb offers one of the most effective digital environments in agriculture, as better attention leads directly to better outcomes.

items.title: Bringing the cows home to Columbus
items.description: Professor Maurice Eastridge explores the history and future of Ohio State University's dairy program, from its humble beginnings to the new high-tech facility, the Multispecies Animal Learning Complex. Find out what it really means to bring the cows home to Columbus. The post Bringing the cows home to Columbus appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The new facility will house a herd of 60 lactating Jersey cows milked by two robotic milking systems, plus 15 dry cows. The $X million project broke ground in January 2024 and the ribbon cutting was held on January 29, 2026.

The new dairy will feature advanced technologies like a Lely Vector automated feeding system and Lely Discovery manure vacuums. Calves will be raised onsite until 6 months old, then moved to the Agricultural Technical Institute (ATI) dairy until 2 months before calving. The facility will also have space for processing milk into value-added products.

Ohio is an important dairy state, ranking 12th nationally in milk production and 1st in Swiss cheese production. The state has about 252,000 dairy cows across 1,400 herds, with 278 robotic milking systems installed so far. Dairy is typically the 3rd or 4th largest agricultural commodity in Ohio.

The new MALC and dairy farm aim to advance sustainability, showcase dairy technology, and continue Ohio State's mission of educating students, conducting dairy research, and engaging the public. The facility will allow cows access to pasture near the Columbus campus to connect the community with animal agriculture.

items.title: What to know about reseeding right-of-ways
items.description: Pipeline easements can disrupt your farm. Learn how to manage reseeding, choose the right forage, and mitigate livestock health risks during land restoration. The post What to know about reseeding right-of-ways appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Landowners are often approached to lease their property for these projects, which can significantly impact their pastures and crops. 

The timeline and priorities of the pipeline company (covering ground to prevent erosion) often conflict with the farmer's concerns over crop impacts, weeds, soil compaction, and proper seeding timing. Farmers need to be proactive in communicating their needs and ensuring the company's reseeding efforts align with their operations.

Recommended seeding options vary by planting window:
- July: Summer annuals like sudangrass, sorghum-sudangrass, pearl millet, teff grass
- Aug/Sept: Oats, triticale, annual ryegrass

Legumes like alfalfa, clovers, and birdsfoot trefoil provide benefits but also risks like bloat. A balanced grass-legume mix is ideal. 

Key prep steps are recommended, including soil testing, weed control, proper inoculation, and equipment calibration. Reaching out to agencies and support networks can help farmers navigate these unscheduled challenges.

items.title: Cold fronting
items.description: This is no longer winter. This is harassment. Through 28 days, northern Ohio has had the coldest January average out of any location in the country. The post Cold fronting appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Some key points:

- Northern Ohio had the coldest January average out of any location in the U.S. through the first 28 days of the month.

- Temperatures were so low that Alaska's capital, Juneau, was 15-25 degrees warmer than Ohio on some days.

- The author's small dog refuses to wear boots and the family has been bringing in farm animals like calves, goats, and bunnies to keep them warm.

- School was canceled for a full week due to the extreme cold snap.

- The author's son, BoyWonder, was able to avoid the cold by traveling to Florida for work, where temperatures were still unseasonably cold at 55 degrees.

- Despite the harsh winters, the author loves living in Ohio and appreciates the state's natural beauty, though wonders how their ancestors chose to settle there.

- The author is hopeful the cold weather will kill off stink bugs, though skeptical it will be effective.

The article provides a vivid, first-hand account of the challenges farmers and residents are facing due to the unprecedented cold front in northern Ohio during this winter season.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The goal was to determine if growers can maintain productivity and profitability while using reduced tillage and cover crops to protect the soil.

The study compared 4 management systems: conventional tillage (CT), fall strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR). Each system was paired with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: unfertilized control, 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac.

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early-season soybean biomass by ~12% but did not affect final yields.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across locations, with no significant differences between tillage systems. 
- When accounting for operational costs, NT had the highest partial net return, followed by ST and CT. NT+CR had the lowest net return due to cover crop management costs.
- The project will continue in 2026 to track longer-term soil and soybean responses in the conservation systems.

The article includes:
- Locations of trials in Illinois and Iowa
- Cereal rye management details (40-50 lb/ac, 1000-1200 lb/ac biomass)
- Soybean planting details (30-in rows, 140,000-150,000 seeds/ac)
- Figures showing soybean growth, leaf nutrient levels, and yield distributions
- Table of estimated costs, revenue, and partial net return for each system

Overall, the results suggest that reduced tillage and cereal rye cover crops can maintain soybean yields compared to conventional tillage, although profitability may be impacted by the higher management costs. Further research is underway to understand longer-term implications.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.

It covers different types of greenhouses and their characteristics, as well as specific crops that can be started early in a greenhouse environment.

Key points:
- Modular plastic greenhouses can raise temperatures up to 30¬∞F higher than outside. They need ventilation.
- Low tunnels and cold frames can also provide 5-15¬∞F of extra warmth.
- Fully fortified designer greenhouses with climate control allow year-round growing.
- Good crops to start in a February greenhouse include tomatoes, peppers, brassicas (kale, cabbage, cauliflower), lettuces, potatoes, and flowers.
- Greenhouse growing helps get a head start on spring crops, protects plants from pests/diseases, and allows for extended growing seasons.
- Key factors are providing consistent warmth, moisture, and light for the crops.

The article does not mention any specific people, organizations, or dates/deadlines. It focuses on general greenhouse growing techniques and recommended crops for a February greenhouse setup.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.
items.summary: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on January 1, 2026. The updated training manuals, available through the ISU Extension Store, are intended to provide Iowans with the basic understanding of effective pesticide use and the information needed to successfully pass the revised certification exams. The updated Iowa Core Manual (CS445) is now available for purchase, and new exams based on the revised core manual are available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites. Additionally, the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1) now includes a two-page informational update, which is provided in each manual, and all private exams now include content from this insert. For more information, contact Betsy Danielson, an extension specialist for Iowa State University Extension and Outreach in the Pesticide Safety Education Program (PSEP).

The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
This approach originated in Brazil's tropical rainforests and can be a good option for farmers with forested land.

Forest farming involves thinning out a forest to create the optimal conditions for growing crops in the understory, such as native ornamentals, fungi, fruit, timber, and forest food crops. It can also involve practices like silvopasture (combining forestry and ranching) and alley cropping (growing crops between rows of trees).

Key benefits of forest farming include:
- Improved water and soil quality
- Carbon sequestration (up to 22 lbs per year in first 20 years)
- Habitat for beneficial insects, birds, mammals, fungi, and bacteria
- Opportunities to grow specialty crops like mushrooms, ramps, syrups, and edible roots

The best candidates for forest farming are farms that already have forested areas or riparian zones with trees. It can be done on a small scale to provide cover for sensitive crops. Farmers should consult their agricultural extension office to develop a forest management plan.

There are also considerations around regulations, especially for wild plants, and the need to be proactive about marketing and selling forest-grown products through avenues like online sales, pick-your-own, and agritourism.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
1. Clarify Objectives: Spray drones can be useful for making applications on wet soils, applying to tall crops, reducing compaction, targeted applications, and supplementing existing spraying capacity.

2. Regulatory Considerations: Farmers need an FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate, FAA Part 137 Certification for aerial pesticide application, and Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) licensing. Only products labeled for aerial use can be applied.

3. Insurance and Risk Management: Farmers need specific coverage for chemical liability, general liability, and drone/equipment damage. Most standard policies do not cover these.

4. Equipment Selection: Consider tank capacity, battery life, nozzle/atomizer options, GPS guidance, and local support when choosing a spray drone system.

5. Training and Safe Operation: Proper training is essential, including gaining flight experience, calibration, weather monitoring, and maintenance.

6. Gradual Adoption: Start on a small scale, compare to conventional methods, and develop efficient procedures before expanding use.

7. Iowa-Based Resources: ISU Extension, Digital Ag Innovation Lab, licensed dealers, and IDALS can provide guidance and support.

8. Future Developments: Ongoing improvements in payload, automation, and integration with precision ag data will shape the long-term role of spray drones.

The article recommends a thoughtful, step-by-step approach to spray drone adoption to ensure compliance, safety, and effective integration into Iowa farming operations.

items.title: Double-crop Soybean Management Practices – Project Report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction There is a growing interest in wheat/soybean double-cropping systems in Illinois, extending into parts of central Illinois where wheat acreage has been limited in recent decades. USDA-NASS survey estimates that 60-80% of Illinois wheat acres are double-cropped with soybeans. Implementing this system in central and northern Illinois has been constrained primarily by low wheat acreage and by later wheat harvest, which often delay
items.summary:
Summary of the Agricultural News Article:

The article reports on a 2-year field trial conducted near Hammond in Piatt County, Illinois to evaluate the effects of soybean maturity group (MG), seeding rate, and starter fertilizer on double-crop soybean yields.

Key Findings:
- Double-crop soybean yields averaged 55.7 bushels/acre in 2024 and 47.8 bushels/acre in 2025.
- Full-season soybean varieties (MG 3.6-3.8) yielded about 4% (2.1 bushels/acre) more than early-maturing varieties (MG 3.0-3.2).
- Yield response to seeding rate differed by maturity group: Early-maturing varieties reached maximum yield (52.3 bu/acre) at 252,000 seeds/acre, while full-season varieties reached maximum yield (53.4 bu/acre) at 207,000 seeds/acre.
- Starter fertilizer (26 lb N, 11 lb S) increased yields by 1.4 bushels/acre (2.6%) in 2024 but had no impact in 2025.

The trials were conducted by the University of Illinois Department of Crop Sciences in collaboration with the Illinois Agricultural Experiment Station, Illinois Fertilizer & Chemical Association, and a local producer. Similar trials across more locations are ongoing to strengthen regional recommendations.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
This protects the seeds while allowing them to be exposed to the cold, moist conditions needed to break dormancy. The result is hardier transplants that mature faster than usual.

Vegetables recommended for winter sowing include:
- Cabbages (standard, Napa, and early-maturing 'Carex' varieties)
- Spinach ('Avon' and 'Space' are good options)
- Onions (long-day, short-day, or intermediate-day varieties depending on latitude) 
- Leafy greens like kale, collards, chard, watercress, and microgreens

Flowers recommended for winter sowing include:
- Pansies
- Echinacea
- Snapdragons (4 groups for different climate conditions)
- Larkspur
- Scabiosa

These plants are well-suited for winter sowing as they can handle cold temperatures and often require a period of cold stratification to germinate properly. Planting them this way gives farmers a head start on the growing season.

The article emphasizes that winter sowing is a great way for farmers to maximize profits and productivity in the spring. It provides detailed advice on selecting the right plants, understanding their growth requirements, and leveraging winter sowing to get a jump on the season.

items.title: 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss
items.description: On today‚Äôs farms, ecologically-friendly practices are on the rise. Using agri-environmental strategies, farmers prevent environmental degradation, preserving natural spaces and the species that live in them. The post 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Prairie Strips - Planting 10-25% of land with prairie strips can attract beneficial predators, improve soil nutrients, and boost yields by attracting pollinators. This increases biodiversity above and below ground.

2. Low Tilling - Reducing tillage and using cover crops can improve soil structure and increase biodiversity of insects and other organisms. This supports both crops and wildlife.

3. Regenerative Grazing - Using rotational grazing, planting native species, and managing invasives can improve pasture health and provide better habitat for local wildlife compared to non-native forage.

4. Integrated Pest Management - Attracting beneficial insects through diverse plantings and cultural practices can reduce reliance on harmful pesticides that kill off habitat.

5. Conservation Easements - Partnering with land trusts to establish conservation easements can protect natural resources and provide tax benefits for farmers with large landholdings.

The article states these strategies can directly correlate to higher soil health, increased biodiversity above and below ground, and better support for multiple species. Implementing even 10-25% of the land in these practices can make a big impact. Experts emphasize farming should work with the natural world instead of against it for long-term sustainability.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29. Each meeting will feature topics tailored to local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.

Topics will include crop market and climate outlooks for 2026, nitrates and drinking water, profitable nutrient management, southern rust, transition planning, and robots/drones.

Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting. Late or on-site registration is $100. Registration includes refreshments, lunch, certified crop advisor credits, and access to resources. Private pesticide applicator recertification will also be available for a $30 fee.

The meetings are designed to provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

"Our goal is always to prepare producers to manage potential issues when they arise, or even before they arise, by sharing the most up-to-date scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers," said Josh Michel, field agronomist with ISU Extension and Outreach.

Registration and more information is available on the Crop Advantage Series registration site. Contacts for questions are crops@iastate.edu and regional ISU Extension and Outreach field agronomists.

items.title: Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists
items.description: Outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon and Wisconsin will be recognized for excellence, leadership and innovation. Kansas City, Mo., (Dec. 15, 2025) ‚Äì Farm Journal has announced three finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, honoring some of the most progressive and successful farm operations in the country. The winner and finalists will be […] The post Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists appeared first
items.summary:
The finalists are:

- Alsum Farms (Friesland, WI) - A multigenerational, 3,600-acre operation producing potatoes, pumpkins, hay, and other crops with a vertically integrated business model.

- Dalton Farms (Wakeman, OH) - A 7th-generation, 2,000-acre corn/soybean farm with a 400-head cattle herd and on-farm market selling local meats and maple syrup.

- Splitter Farms (Sterling, KS) - A 1,400-acre owned, 18,500-acre total row crop operation using data-driven management after the owner's father passed away in 2010.

The winner and finalists will be recognized at the 2026 Top Producer Summit in Nashville, TN on February 9-11. The $10,000 Next Generation Award will go to Tim Nuss (El Dorado Hills/Lodi, CA) for his diversified farming and ag tech entrepreneurship. The $5,000 Women in Agriculture Award will be awarded to Helle Ruddenklau (Amity, OR) for her leadership in Oregon's agriculture industry. The awards are sponsored by BASF, Fendt, Pioneer, and Pro Farmer.

items.title: Still an opportunity to attend the ICM Conference!
items.description: This year we are offering on-site registration for the Integrated Crop Managem
items.summary: The Iowa State University Integrated Crop Management (ICM) Conference will be held on December 10-11, 2025 at the Meadows Events and Conference Center in Altoona, IA. The conference will feature 33 workshops covering topics like crops, pests, nutrient management, and conservation. Attendees can earn up to 14 continuing education credits for Certified Crop Advisers, as well as Iowa Commercial Pesticide Applicator continuing instruction for 2025 in categories 1A, 1B, 1C, and 4 for an additional fee. items.description:

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop compared to corn. Sorghum is more drought-tolerant, has lower nitrogen requirements, and is not susceptible to the tar spot pathogen. Experts will discuss sorghum's production and utilization for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

Speakers will include:
- Mitch Tuinstra, Wickersham Chair of Excellence in Agricultural Research and scientific director of the Institute for Plant Sciences at Purdue, who will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality.
- Brad Shelton, FPAC superintendent
- Jason Tower, Southern Indiana Purdue Agricultural Center superintendent
- Nick Minton, Purdue Extension beef systems specialist
- Jeff Jackson, Croplan alfalfa and forage specialist

The event will include venue tours, a dinner, and a bull test station tour. Those with questions or accessibility needs can contact Keith Johnson, Purdue professor of agronomy.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Farmer sentiment improved in July 2024, with the Purdue/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer rising 8 points to 113.

- The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.

- Despite declines in corn (11%) and soybean (5%) prices, farmers reported fewer worsened conditions compared to a year ago and fewer expected negative future outcomes.

- The top concerns for farmers were high input costs (34%) and the risk of lower crop/livestock prices (29%).

- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points to 81, reflecting worries about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.

- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points to 38, but remains 7 points lower than July 2023, as 75% still believe it's a bad time for large investments.

- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118, while the Long-Term index dropped 6 points to 146.

- 72% of crop farmers expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same in 2025 compared to 2024.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers are taking an interdisciplinary approach to assessing the emerging tar spot disease in corn. The disease, which had been endemic in several Latin American countries since 1904, was first detected in the U.S. in 2015 and has since spread to 16 states and Ontario, Canada.

The research team, led by C.D. Cruz, associate professor of botany and plant pathology at Purdue, is using a mix of statistical analysis, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision to better understand the dynamics of tar spot in corn. Their work is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million.

The researchers are collaborating with colleagues in Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S. to address biosecurity challenges and provide rapid and accurate information to stakeholders. They have developed a digital method for quantifying tar spot in corn, which they have tested under field conditions against human raters.

Another research effort involves the laboratory of Purdue's Mohammad Jahanshahi, who has adapted his AI and computer-vision approaches from monitoring civil infrastructure to inspecting and analyzing agricultural disease epidemiology. Mariela Fern√°ndez-Campos, a PhD student, and Abhishek Subedi, a PhD student in civil engineering, are working on a proof-of-concept data fusion project that integrates drone imagery and weather data to capture crucial details about the tar spot pathosystem.

The team aims to quantify and model tar spot severity by referencing and integrating imagery with spatial and temporal data, ultimately providing farmers with rapid and accurate information about the disease.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary:
The new UW Madison publication "Potassium Cycle" provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The 2-page publication outlines key potassium concepts, including:

- Potassium is an essential nutrient for plant growth and development, playing a role in photosynthesis, drought resistance, and overall plant health.
- Potassium enters the soil through weathering of minerals, organic matter decomposition, and fertilizer application. It is taken up by crops, can leach, and is also removed in harvested products.
- Optimal potassium levels in soil are 100-200 ppm. Deficient levels can reduce yields, while excess potassium can antagonize other nutrient uptake.
- Soil testing is recommended to determine potassium needs. Fertilizer application rates should be based on crop removal and soil test results.
- Cover cropping, manure application, and reducing tillage can help retain potassium in the soil system.

The publication is available free of charge from the UW Madison Nutrient and Pest Management (NPM) program. Farmers are encouraged to review the resource to better understand the potassium cycle and optimize potassium management for their operations.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary: The 2023 Wisconsin winter wheat crop is developing 10-14 days ahead of average due to the warm weather. As of mid-April, 80% of the state's winter wheat was in the jointing stage, compared to the typical 50-60% at this time. However, the advanced growth stage increases the risk of frost damage. Farmers are advised to closely monitor their fields and consider frost protection measures if temperatures drop below 24¬∞F. Despite the early progress, overall winter wheat condition in Wisconsin is reported as 72% good to excellent, slightly lower than the 5-year average of 75%. Experts recommend that farmers scout fields regularly, apply fungicides proactively, and stay up-to-date on the latest weather forecasts to manage the 2023 winter wheat crop effectively.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
Key points:

- Soybean plant stands can be reduced early in the season due to abiotic factors (freezing, hail, flooding) or biotic factors (slugs, deer, disease, insects).
- The optimal plant population for soybeans is 100,000-150,000 plants per acre. Stands below 80,000 plants per acre may warrant replanting.
- Factors to evaluate include current plant population, growth stage, growing conditions, and expected yield of the current stand vs. a replanted crop.
- Replanting should be done within 7-10 days of the initial planting to maximize yield potential. Later replanting can result in up to 10% yield reduction.
- Replanting expenses include seed, fuel, labor, and potential crop insurance implications. Weighing costs vs. expected yield increase is important.
- Shawn P. Conley, a soybean and small grains specialist at UW-Madison, advises carefully evaluating the field before making a replanting decision.

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
Key points:

- 2,4-D may be used for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybeans, but there are important considerations for farmers to be aware of.
- The EPA approved the registration of 2,4-D for use on Enlist E3 soybeans, but this approval expires on December 20, 2023. Farmers need to be aware of this deadline.
- Rodrigo Werle, a weed scientist and extension specialist at UW-Madison, recommends that farmers consult with their local extension office or chemical dealer to ensure they are using 2,4-D products in compliance with the label and relevant regulations.
- Werle also advises farmers to be cautious of potential off-target movement of 2,4-D, which can damage nearby susceptible crops. He recommends following all label instructions carefully.
- The article does not provide any specific data or statistics, but emphasizes the importance of staying informed and compliant when using 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybeans in 2024.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary:
The Wisconsin Certified Crop Advisor (CCA) Board election results are as follows:

Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura have been elected to the Wisconsin CCA Board. The election process was overseen by the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

The newly elected board members will serve 3-year terms. Their responsibilities will include providing guidance and support to Wisconsin's network of over 1,000 CCAs, who play a crucial role in promoting sustainable agriculture practices.

CCAs are agricultural professionals certified by the American Society of Agronomy to provide expert advice to farmers on topics like nutrient management, pest control, and crop production. There are currently over 13,000 CCAs across the United States and Canada.

The Wisconsin CCA program is funded in part by the Wisconsin Corn Promotion Board and the Wisconsin Soybean Marketing Board. These organizations represent the state's corn and soybean farmers respectively.
